awd_titl_txt: Travel Grant: Workshop on Research Directions for the Grid Edge, To Be Held   March 24-25, in  Alexandria, VA
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal requests funding to provide travel subsidies for university professors to attend the NSF Workshop to define the Research Directions for the Grid Edge: Interfacing the Legacy Grids Operated by Utilities with Emerging Grids Owned and Operated by Third Parties at the Edge. The workshop focusing on unresolved problems, technology requirements and research directions for the time horizon of 5-10 years will be held in Washington DC on March 24-25, 2020. This workshop intends to bring the travel grant recipients, as well as industry and government stakeholders together to address the Grid Edge concepts, fundamentals and vision holistically. The proposed workshop will offer a forum to discuss and coordinate a research strategy and related action plan to meet industry needs for new solutions in response to the new developments affecting the grid. The grid edge is considered a crucial development for the future of the electricity grids requires contributions from academics, engineers, policy makers, economists, social scientists, government officials, and technology leaders in delivering solutions for the next generation electricity grid for the benefits of the society.

The fundamental concepts needed for advancing the grid Edge require an interdisciplinary approach involving basic research, applied engineering, technology innovation, behavioral studies, market economics, and policy insights. The grid edge is defined in this context through multiple dimensions: a) the asset ownership, which entails the utility owned and non-utility owned assets, b) the edge stakeholder role, which encompasses the utility-centric and third party-centric view, and the view that focuses on the need to closely collaborate across the edge boundaries, and c) the structured operational layers covering physical grid components, control and protection, the technology, cyber-physical security and privacy, markets, regulatory framework, and business models. This workshop will continue the NSF past and current efforts undertaken through a recent series of timely workshops to offer additional research insight and a perspective focusing on the cyber and physical aspects of energy generation and consumption at the grid edge.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Problems to be solved. The grid at the edge expansion involves the consumer premises (households, commercial and industrial sites). Currently, utilities are not typically investing in distributed energy resources (DERs) which include rooftop photovoltaic (PV) systems as well as stationary or mobile battery energy storage located at the customer sites. Since DER assets may be owned by the premises owners or a third party, future grid expansion at the edge of the existing grid needs to have a policy and regulatory framework that enables close coordination between the utility operators and owners and between the operators and owners of DERs. This coordination spans technical, market and social equity issues. While the penetration of DERs is currently relatively low, it is expected to grow at a rapid pace due to environmental and competitive reasons; it was thus recognized that there is a need for a national electricity grid growth vision that will encompass the research efforts and technology standardization to address the fundamental and practical challenges. A major part of the vision is the need for the economic incentives and market rules that will stimulate the investment in DER growth. The expectation is that the societal goal for the expansion of the grid edge will stimulate innovation and offer electricity supply solutions that are reliable, resilient, fair, safe and secure.

Fundamental and practical challenges. One main fundamental challenge is that the existing grid was not designed to accommodate large penetrations of DERs. This creates barriers when the traditional customers become prosumers, meaning that they may have access to the control and information technology (CIT), as well as the energy resource infrastructure that allows them to consume or produce energy depending on their needs and economic incentives. With such prosumer resources, often called virtual power plants (VPPs), the interfacing to the legacy grid may involve bidirectional power flows with the loads connected through smart inverters, making the operation and planning of the traditional grid much more complex than what it is today. Such developments ask for new monitoring, control and protection paradigms, as well as new architectural solutions that can be flexible enough to accommodate a variety of operating scenarios that may dynamically change in real time. Since the reliability of solutions may not be achievable through traditional well-accepted cost-sensitive solutions, the reliability criteria have to be complemented with the resilience criteria for system operation under a variety of new operating conditions partially caused by weather conditions resulting from climate change trends. The growth of the grid at the edge requires solutions that are backward compatible, interoperable and trustworthy making the integration of the new and legacy solutions seamless.    

Recommendations. The recommendations span across several use-inspired research areas: a) heuristic large-scale optimization, b) centralized, distributed and coordinated control supported by enhanced sensors and reliable communications, c) integration of smart inverters with the monitoring, control and protection functionalities, d) use of data sciences and artificial intelligence to complement the traditional physics-based models, e) enhancement of the high-fidelity models of the edge devices and systems, f) social, behavioral and economics studies of consumer interaction, g) the use of digital twins for cyber-physical modeling and simulation, h) outage risk analysis based on integration of data and physical models, i) cyberphysical security with imbedded solutions for attack and ransomware denial and j) rate structures that create incentives for aggregated participation of DERs in wholesale and retail markets. Those research areas are already indicated as the focus areas in the NSF research portfolio, but integration of such concepts into a future framework that can accommodate sustainable growth at the grid edge may require close collaboration with industry and government labs, so creation of consortia and research centers with the focus on the grid edge is highly recommended. A part of the integration effort is also development of large-scale testbeds in collaboration with industry and Federal labs that can be used to evaluate new concepts and validate fundamental hypothesis.

Transformational and Convergent Research. The NSF agency goals have been to advance the transformational and convergent issues across all the disciplines. The grid edge requires even tighter collaboration between Energy, Power, Control and Networks (EPCN) (ENG/ECCS), Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE), and Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE) Programs and Directorates than what has been the practice so far. The physical domain of the grid edge, traditionally covered by the EPCN research effort, needs to be supplemented by research discoveries in the CISE and SBE areas to create synergetic outcomes needed for new conceptual frameworks paving the way for grid expansion in the future. Since the electricity infrastructure interacts closely with other critical infrastructures covering the gas, water, transportation, communications and financial domains, coordinated research across larger teams may be needed to add transformational and convergent components not easily achieved by individual researchers.  research.
